comment._content: I can't get very close in Google street view, this is the best I can do. Just left of the red car is the bridge over the railway visible in the original, and the same house can be seen too. The railway is, of course, gone. Wikipedia suggests that the last train ran in 1953.

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content:
Hi swordscookie:  Don't know about a kayak, but the Caragh River is very popular with canoeists.  The train ran through tunnels along the Hill of Drung, which sweeps directly into Dingle Bay.  Then and earlier there was Mountain Stage before the hill, as even horse carriages couldn't travel it at one time.

'Is this the Hill of Drung, a lady visiting the O'Connells asked in astonishment. 'Yes, Mam,' her O'Connell guide answered, 'And if my master knew you were coming sooner he'd have levelled it before you.'

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Thank you Myrtle, but craic in a canoe does not have quite the same ring to it;-)  Can you imagine the tourist atraction the railway would be today????

comment._content: Excelente.

comment._content: Had the Last Train done the Cahirciveen - Killarney journey by the time this photo was taken?  I remember collecting my brother (from school in Dublin) in Cahirciveen station after the broken nose hurling incident, then later he had to catch the train/be collected from Killarney.

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: Yes. It looks as if the Hill of Drung is in the far distance.  Your picture is from the Killarney side of Glenbeigh whereas the Hill is far beyond it.  The Kennelly Archive has a picture of the last train to Cahersiveen in December 1960 and other pictures also.  I read somewhere that the last train from Tralee to Dingle closed in 1953, so don't know how that date got included here. The line that ran to Cahersiveen and Renard Point, opposite Valentia, was very scenic and it was shortsighted to close it.  The train service could have been suspended until times improved

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I got that 1953 date wrong, as you say, that's for the Dingle line. BTW, Glinsk! (or often, Gleesk or even Gleensk).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mosskayree] Thanks. We have some pictures of the two tunnels that might be good to add here. You have me wondering about the date now, but O'Dea photos are usually spot on and very reliable date-wise... Here's one near the Hill of Drung from much earlier days.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mosskayree] Actually, remembering the Hill of Drung shot, here's PeetThePhotographer's comment from a few months ago: "Farranfore to Valentia Harbour railway in service from 1893 till 1960. It was the most Western railway in Europe."
